newsitem.title: INDIA: Gold - Indian sub-continent prices stay subdued.
newsitem.headline: Gold - Indian sub-continent prices stay subdued.

text.p: Gold was subdued in the Indian sub-continent in the week to Monday and dealers said they expected prices to weaken further on poor demand.
Bombay dealers said seasonal gold buying had not been up to market expectations while improved supplies had prompted selling.
In the week to Monday standard gold dropped 25 rupees per 10 grammes to 4,790 rupees.
Dealers said supplies had improved in the last two months following a liberal gold import policy announced by the Indian government on December 31.
India allowed expatriates to bring in 10 kg of gold once every six months, subject to a duty of 220 rupees per 10 grammes, against five kg permitted earlier.
Dealers said the measure helped boost gold supplies in January, which also coincided with the peak Indian wedding season that lasted until mid-February.
Low world market prices towards the end of the previous year had also prompted Indian expatriates to buy gold.
World markets have since recovered.
"But sentiment in India is subdued and I am expecting gold prices to remain subdued in the coming days," said Babubhai Jain, a Bombay bullion dealer.
Dealers in Pakistan's main commercial centre of Karachi said they would expect gold prices to remain mixed this week in line with international price trends.
Gold prices in Pakistan depended on international rates, which were mixed last week, dealer Farooq Qureshi said.
In the week to Saturday, gold prices improved by 26 rupees per 10 grammes to 4,728 rupees on the Karachi bullion market.

In Dubai too, gold demand was subdued, but traders expected interest to rise in the run-up to a month-long shopping promotion which was likely to lure big jewellery and investment bar buyers to the souk.

"Coins and jewellery are the main attraction," said a retailer, referring to the commemorative gold coin which would be minted especially for the festival, which organisers hoped would attract tourists, particularly from the Indian subcontinent, the Gulf and Europe.
